statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: California 65, Oregon 62
article.story: BERKELEY, Calif. (AP) -- California coach Ben Braun didn't breathe easily until Oregon's final shot fell short of the rim. Oregon coach Ernie Kent thought the game was decided much earlier than that. Marquise Kately scored 11 of his 15 points in the second half and Cal hung on for its fifth straight home victory over Oregon, 65-62 on Thursday night. Rod Benson had 15 points and six rebounds for the Golden Bears (10-8, 3-5 Pac-10), who built on their momentum from last weekend's road win over UCLA, which snapped a four-game losing streak. Braun credited the victory to his players' energy, which has increased exponentially since a tough practice last Friday in Los Angeles. The Bears were more aggressive on defense and on the boards, and the Ducks (11-6, 3-5) were slow to match them. "I saw a team that really wanted a game," Braun said. "They came focused to practice this week. I thought our team's spirit has been good, and that's hard when your leading scorer (Richard Midgley) is out injured. Our guys never hung their heads. Their effort and their will is getting better." Dominic McGuire matched his career high with 12 points in the first half, and Cal then held off several rallies by the Ducks in the final minutes for its seventh win in the rivalry's last 10 games. Malik Hairston scored 15 points for the Ducks, who lost for the fifth time in seven games. The Bay Area road trip has been ugly for the Ducks, who haven't won in Berkeley since Feb. 12, 2000 -- and haven't won at Stanford since Jan. 13, 1986. But Oregon wasted several chances for a win at Haas Pavilion. The Ducks started slowly, going without a 3-pointer in the first half, and never reclaimed the lead despite several chances. Ernie Kent is frustrated enough with his starters' recent first-half efforts to contemplate changes to the lineup. "It's called starting the game with a sense of urgency," he said. "We just dug too much of a hole in the first half. ... We lost on Oregon's inability to execute. We had 18 turnovers, and we didn't keep them off the boards. I'm proud of the way we fought back, but we just didn't get it done." The Ducks trailed by 12 early in the second half, but Aaron Brooks' 3-pointer with 2:06 to play capped an 18-8 run that cut Cal's lead to one point. After Kately made two free throws, Brandon Lincoln made a layup to pull Oregon within 63-62. Cal's Martin Smith then missed a free throw -- but Brooks missed an open 3-pointer with 20 seconds left, and Ayinde Ubaka sealed Cal's win on two free throws with 11.1 seconds left. Jordan Kent scored 10 points for the Ducks, but airballed a 3-pointer in the closing minutes before missing a long leaning shot at the buzzer, allowing Braun to exhale. Brooks finished with 11 points, well below his team-leading average. "We can compete with anybody," said Ubaka, who had nine points, four assists and four steals in just his fourth game back from a broken foot. "We just have to bring it together. We have a lot of talent. The last couple of games, we've brought it together." Both programs are rebuilding, with no seniors on either roster -- and the Bears played their third straight game without Midgley, who will try to play again Saturday against Oregon State despite his injured right shoulder. Cal took a 41-29 lead early in the second half on the first of two alley-oop dunks by McGuire, but Oregon hit three consecutive 3-pointers during a 13-2 run to stay close. Cal responded with 10 straight points, but the Ducks made another run in the final minutes.
